links.title: China's smartphone shipments bounce back from pandemic lows, but chip shortage and Covid still weigh
links.description: Chinese domestic smartphone shipments recovered from the hit they took during the pandemic but have still not recovered to pre-Covid levels, according to government data. The smartphone industry has been constrained by various factors, from the global semiconductor shortage to disruption from Covid outbreaks in China.

$SPY $QQQ $AAPL Watch UK's markets, they about to cliff-dive at open, $FTSE . Others too , will be butterfly effector Europe, 'course reverberations from our market down.

I expect huge drops today there. 

UK been very reluctant to raise rates same with European Central Bank but Engkand's inflation isca warning sign and although Germany was in-line for it's YoY CPi, 5.3% IS STILL HIGH! 😱🚨

Very likely both British MPC rate policy Committee and ECB now THRUST INTO THE having to do what they were not planning on doing at their respective policymaking "FED" meetings in Feb. 3 , for UK, and March 3 for EUC.

Scary-scary times.

I've been preaching in USA: Inflation will rule the day (for years).

Now, go ahead, repeat those words for Europe & UK. The beast rearing its head there now too👀🥶

links.title: UK inflation rate soars to 30-year high as cost pressures continue
links.description: LONDON - The U.K. inflation rate soared to a 30-year high in December as higher energy costs, resurgent demand and supply chain issues continued to drive up consumer prices. Inflation hit an annual 5.4%, its highest since March 1992 and up from 5.1% in November, itself a decade high.

links.title: German 10-year bond yield trades in positive territory for the first time since May 2019
links.description: Borrowing costs for the German government continued their push higher on Wednesday, with the benchmark 10-year bund yield trading in positive territory for the first time in nearly three years. May 2019 was the last time that German 10-year yields were above zero when accommodative policy from the European Central Bank pressured interest rates lower.

$AAPL FACT OF THE DAY...

As inflation is causing interest rates to increase by approx 1 - 1.5%, it is rumoured on WS that the majority of companies related to the Nasdaq and Russell WILL NOT BE MAKING ANY MONEY for the foreseeable future. 

Hence the absolute slaying of both these markets.

Did you know that?
